channel.title: Worse than SOPA: Stop CISPA
channel.description: Half of it's real, half of it isn't. Look it up :P

item.title: Worse than SOPA: Stop CISPA
item.dc:creator: @imsuperman05 imsuperman05
item.description:
@imsuperman05 wrote:

isn’t this the reason why the founding fathers wrote the constitution: to leave us the fuck alone and have our privacy. i say fuck the government. why dont they worry about the fucking humongous debt instead of trying to pass stupid, pointless bills

eyeownyew:

We aren’t like, China, damnit… This shouldn’t even be possible

I believe it’s going to turn from this to allowing military related members to also be selected for government positions.

item.title: Worse than SOPA: Stop CISPA
item.dc:creator: @ox_random_xi ox random xi
item.description:
@ox_random_xi wrote:

[quote=“t4, post:6, topic:438829”][quote author=ox random xi link=topic=541537.msg3966990#msg3966990 date=1333814136]

not sure if… troll

It’s real…
[/quote]

“This one’s not at all like SOPA,” said Rep. Mike Rogers (R-MI), who helped introduce the bill to the House late last year. “SOPA had an O in it. CISPA sounds more like Vespa. More fun. We think America will really like it.”

And unlike SOPA, the new CISPA has support from big-name players like AT&T, Verizon and Facebook. Whereas its predecessor put companies at risk for subscriber activity, CISPA rewards companies for collecting data, intercepting or modifying communications, and handing information over to the government.

“This time we’re not a threat. We’re a partner,” said Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, enjoying a second helping of spicy Buffalo wings at a CISPA party on Capitol Hill last Wednesday.

ARE YOU SURE?

edit: http://rt.com/usa/news/cispa-bill-sopa-internet-175/
wtf.[/quote]
Yeah I don’t trust a lot of articles.
http://intelligence.house.gov/bill/cyber-intelligence-sharing-and-protection-act-2011

^ that’s the real bill.

Read full topic

“This one’s not at all like SOPA,” said Rep. Mike Rogers (R-MI), who helped introduce the bill to the House late last year. “SOPA had an O in it. CISPA sounds more like Vespa. More fun. We think America will really like it.”

And unlike SOPA, the new CISPA has support from big-name players like AT&T, Verizon and Facebook. Whereas its predecessor put companies at risk for subscriber activity, CISPA rewards companies for collecting data, intercepting or modifying communications, and handing information over to the government.

“This time we’re not a threat. We’re a partner,” said Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg, enjoying a second helping of spicy Buffalo wings at a CISPA party on Capitol Hill last Wednesday.

ARE YOU SURE?
